citations.narrative:
While observing alpaca interactions with the public a readily identifiable employee could not be found. Two large outdoor
pasture enclosures that are approximately ½ acre in size and housing 20 alpacas of various ages in each enclosure allow
for self-guided interactions and feeding. When identifiable employees were observed they were cleaning or performing
other tasks and not monitoring the interactions with the animals. Additionally, in the goat barn, which houses 34 goats,
there was a readily identifiable attendant in the indoor section of the barn, but this individual was unable to observe the
interactions with the goats in the outdoor portion of the barn simultaneously.
A responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods
of public contact. The facility must provide an adequate number of attendants to ensure any interactions with the animals
are conducted in a safe manner for both the animals and the public.
Correct by 30 October 2024

The outdoor section of an enclosure that contains a pond water feature housing 2 capybaras does not have an adequate
perimeter fence surrounding the enclosure. One side of the outdoor enclosure is surrounded by a wire livestock fence that
measures 4 feet in height and a second side of the enclosure is surrounded by a metal bar fence that does not exceed 4
feet in height. The third side of the enclosure is surrounded by a deck with railing that does meet the 6 feet requirement in
some areas but only measures 5.5 feet on one side of the deck.
The lack of an adequate perimeter fence can allow unwanted animals or people to enter the enclosure and potentially
harm the animals within. The lack of a perimeter fence does not allow for a secondary containment for the animals and
can lead to escape. The perimeter fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting
animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and
so that it can function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient height (at
least six feet high) to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. It must be of sufficient distance (at least three feet)
from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals
or persons outside the perimeter fence.
Correct by 30 May 2025
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by 26 November 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License
Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
Lauren Murphy, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
While observing alpaca interactions with the public a readily identifiable employee could not be found. Two large outdoor 
pasture enclosures that are approximately ½ acre in size and housing 20 alpacas of various ages in each enclosure allow 
for self-guided interactions and feeding. When identifiable employees were observed they were cleaning or performing 
other tasks and not monitoring the interactions with the animals. Additionally, in the goat barn, which houses 34 goats, 
there was a readily identifiable attendant in the indoor section of the barn, but this individual was unable to observe the 
interactions with the goats in the outdoor portion of the barn simultaneously.  
A responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods 
of public contact. The facility must provide an adequate number of attendants to ensure any interactions with the animals 
are conducted in a safe manner for both the animals and the public. 
Correct by 30 October 2024 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The outdoor section of an enclosure that contains a pond water feature housing 2 capybaras does not have an adequate 
perimeter fence surrounding the enclosure. One side of the outdoor enclosure is surrounded by a wire livestock fence that 
measures 4 feet in height and a second side of the enclosure is surrounded by a metal bar fence that does not exceed 4 
feet in height. The third side of the enclosure is surrounded by a deck with railing that does meet the 6 feet requirement in 
some areas but only measures 5.5 feet on one side of the deck.  
The lack of an adequate perimeter fence can allow unwanted animals or people to enter the enclosure and potentially 
harm the animals within. The lack of a perimeter fence does not allow for a secondary containment for the animals and 
can lead to escape. The perimeter fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting 
animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and 
so that it can function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient height (at 
least six feet high) to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. It must be of sufficient distance (at least three feet) 
from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals 
or persons outside the perimeter fence. 
Correct by 30 May 2025

This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by 26 November 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the 
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License 
Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Lauren Murphy, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
